content: It should come as no surprise, but

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: easily passes The Cooz Test. That's the one where

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: wants to know what's the ballhandler's first instinct as he brings the ball over halfcourt. You pass The Cooz Test if your first instinct is to pass the basketball.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: The Nets' point guard went into last night's game against the Celtics needing eight assists to tie the Cooz for 12th place for career assists. He only got four, his lowest output in 15 games. It's only a matter of time, of course, and the Cooz, with 6,955 career dimes, is not the least bit perturbed he's going to drop another notch. Especially at the expense of Kidd.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: "Jason Kidd is the purest of the point guards who's out there," Cousy said yesterday by telephone from Florida, where he is busy getting his handicap down to an 8. "Defensively, he's right there. And offensively, I think he's the most creative at the position since

content: was your working man's point guard -- just solid. I think Kidd is a little more creative."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span

content: Cousy was asked if he's now so accustomed to seeing players pass him that it's hardly worth noting.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: "This may surprise you," he said, "but I have no idea how many assists I got. Or points. We just weren't into the individual stuff. But ask me about the six championships and we can talk all day."

content: , on the injured list with a right ankle sprain and thought to be out at least four weeks, may be ready to

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p i span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: by the weekend, 10 days after the injury occurred. "He's making an unbelievable recovery," coach

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: said before last night's game. Jefferson suffered the injury against the Pacers Jan. 26 and has been diligently rehabbing since. Last night was the fourth game he missed of a minimum of five; he also will miss tomorrow night's game against Orlando. After that, all bets are off. Rivers thinks Jefferson may be able to practice today, although Jefferson expressed surprise when told of the coach's remarks. "I think Doc misses me," Jefferson said. "I think he misses yelling at me." Jefferson would be eligible to return for the Super Bowl Sunday game in Minnesota. Rivers hinted that that might be a distinct possibility, but Big Al said he'd wait until everyone weighed in. "Better safe than sorry," he said. A quick Jefferson return is likely bad news for

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p i span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: ankle, Googs) and head back to the IL. Googs ended up logging a healthy 17 minutes last night, matching his longest stint of the season . . .

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span
html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p span
content: was limited to eight first-half minutes and then was told to go home. Rivers said Davis had the flu and Davis certainly played like something was wrong. He had one bizarre possession in which he nearly lost the ball three times, and then went up for a jumper and came down without the ball, but without attempting a shot. "I thought that was one of my better coaching decisions," Rivers said of sending Davis home . . . The Nets had to play without starting center

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span

content: in the second half. He was down with an upper respiratory infection. New Jersey had 10 available players, but two of them,

content: , had been with the team for only one game. "Seems like we lose a player every day," Kidd said. "We've got to get some bodies. We cannot continue to keep playing 45 minutes a night." Kidd went 32 minutes last night and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td div div div div div p b span

content: went 29 . . . Rivers on Carter: "He's playing as well as I've seen him -- ever. He's scoring, assisting, playing defense, doing all the things a lot of people said he wouldn't do. Good for him."
